stem: The nurse is orienting new staff to the unit. For each staff action involving technology, select whether it is Clinically Appropriate or a Professional Violation.

rows.text: Using a personal smartphone to photograph a rare skin rash for a medical student's education.
Logging off a workstation while stepping away for 30 seconds to get a water pitcher.
Using a secure hospital-encrypted messaging app to clarify an order with a physician.
Checking a former patient's EHR to see if they were successfully discharged after your shift ended.

rationale.correct: Digital ethics are clear in HIPAA/2026 standards. (r1) Even for education, personal phones must *never* be used for clinical photos; only hospital-vetted devices with consent are allowed. (r2) Proper workstation security. (r3) Use of secure, hospital-approved tools is appropriate. (r4) Accessing a chart for curiosity (without a 'need to know' for current care) is a violation of the Privacy Rule.
rationale.incorrect: Curiosity and educational good intentions do not justify bypassing encryption and privacy laws.
clinicalPearls: 'Need to know' is the primary standard for EHR access. If you aren't currently caring for the patient, don't open the chart.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that caring about a patient's outcome doesn't give you the legal right to their chart once they are no longer on your assignment.

mnemonic.title: S-L-O-W
mnemonic.expansion: Secure app, Log off, Only clinical devices, Watch your 'need-to-know'.

reviewUnits.heading: Technology and Patient Privacy
reviewUnits.body: Digital devices offer efficiency but pose significant risks for privacy breaches. Nurses must strictly adhere to the HIPAA Security Rule regarding password sharing, device use, and access logs.
